oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Howard Deal, Margaret Deal, and Earlie Deal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Dickson County residents Howard Deal, Margaret Deal, and Earlie Deal recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. They describe opening their family sorghum mill in White Bluff in 1921. The step-by-step process of sorghum and molassas making is explained. The Deal's share family history and the challenges of running a sorghum mill. They also touch on field hollers or karo-ing, whistling, farming practices, livestock, and music.

The Deal's contribution conveys elements of Dickson County's agricultural history. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. From those bases, they conducted interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Genealogy; Field Hollers; Foodways; Sorghum
Animals; legends; photographs
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lawless, Elaine
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Library and Archives

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Taylor Jefferson (T. J.) Box, Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Henderson County resident T.J. Box, "Uncle Jake," recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Box relates details of his personal history and travels, recounts baseball stories, and supplies recitations and unaccompanied old time music vocals.

During the course of his life, Box pursued agricultural work, migrant work, work in a canning plant, and life insurance. His travels took him to California, Florida, Alabama, and Arkansas. Born in Lawrence County, Tennessee, he would eventually come back to the state of his birth and reside in the Blue Goose Community, outside Lexington, Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Family histories; Photographs; Recitations; Vocal ensembles, Unaccompanied; Old-time music

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Emanuel Dupree
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Fayette County resident Emanuel Dupree recorded as part of the Tennessee State Park Folklife Project. Dupree, a third generation white oak basket maker and chair bottomer, describes the processes and how he learned. This African American woodcrafter also relates performing in local fife and drum bands and the accompanying celebrations.

Dupree's contribution beautifully illustrates the transmittal of folk art skills through African American family networks. Dupree has been called one of the leading 20th century makers of split baskets. His Fayette County fife and drum band gained national attention and joined the list of surviving black fife and drum bands in Mississippi and Georgia. This tradition, arising in the South after the Civil War, and loosely based on militia bands, centered around performances at summer holiday picnics.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Basket Makers; Fife and drum corps
Basket Making; Baskets
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jeffrey, Robert

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ed Harris, Emanuel Dupree, James Tatum, et al Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Fayette County residents Ed Harris, Emanuel Dupree, James Tatum, and Annie Marie Valentine recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Together, participants perform and communicate the background behind African American blues, religious, and old time music with the fife, fife and drum bands, and unaccompanied vocals. Toasts and humorous tales are also conveyed.

The Fayette County fife and drum band represented by this contribution gained national attention and joined the list of surviving black fife and drum bands in Mississippi and Georgia. This tradition, arising in the South after the Civil War, and looselybased on militia bands, centered around black community picnics. The picnics occurred during the summer and often on holidays such as July Fourth or Labor Day.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ballads; Fife; Blues (Music); Old-time music; Sacred music; Fife and drump corps; Storytelling; Toasts
Baskets

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Porter Linder Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Fentress County resident Porter Linder recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Tales of Stearns Logging illustrate the commercial logging that came to the Big South Fork area between 1900 and 1920. The logging camps, logging trains, and large-scale operations of Michigan-based Stearns Coal and Lumber Company are conveyed. Linder speaks of the tragic 1933 lumber camp shooting sparked by Jerome Boyatt that rocked the Big South Fork area and resulted in five deaths.

Linder's contribution illustrates the impact commercial lumber and coal ventures of northern investors had on areas like Scott, Pickett, and Fentress Counties. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. From those bases, they conducted interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Logging; Personal narratives
Bootlegging; Photographs; Lynchings
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Allen, Ray

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oak Grove Acapella Singers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Chester County's Oak Grove Acapella Singers performing recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Fifteen members comprise this unaccompanied African American religious musical group centered around the Oak Grove Church of Christ of Jacks Creek, Tennessee. The singers perform gospel songs that feature solos by several of the members.

The contribution of the Oak Grove Acapella Singers conveys the power of African American gospel and the rich tradition of acapella religious performances in some denominations. The Tennessee State Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. From those bases, they conducted interviews, took photos, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dick Huddleston Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Wilson County resident Dick Huddleston's oral history recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Huddleston, a Cedars of Lebanon 39-year park employee, farmer, and resident of the area, describes many farms and businesses that existed before the establishment of Cedars of Lebanon State Park. Huddleston, the first park ranger of Cedars of Lebanon State Park, speaks of various homesteads that eventually became part of the park.

Huddleston's contribution furnishes, not only family history, but Wilson County business, agricultural, and architectural history and history of the Cedars of Lebanon State Park. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. They conducted interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Wilson County (Tenn.); Personal Narratives; Genealogy; Folk Architecture; Anecdotes;
Cemeteries; Death; Stone Masonry
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lawless, Elaine

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Willard Walton Part 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Macon County resident Willard Walton recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Walton, a folk artist, performer, and sassafras tea seller, relates his family history and talks about his creative process. He demonstrates woodworking and whittling by creating animals from tree stumps and tree roots. Walton speaks of creating musical instruments fashioned from found objects and of his paintings and drawings.

Walton's contribution highlights a multi-medium folk artist inspired by his family history, his natural surroundings, his life experiences, and his military service in India. His woodcraft gained national prominence, and advertisements for his walking sticks appeared in New York Magazine as early as the 1970s. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: American folkways; Sculpture; Herbal teas; Sassafras; Musical Instruments; Wood-carving
Painting

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Alma Lee Hodgin Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Cumberland County resident Alma Lee Hodgin recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Hodgin accompanies herself on the guitar, while singing examples of ballads and old time, religious, and country music. Hodgin describes learning to sing, to play the guitar, and to master songs from generations of family members

Hodgins's contribution emphasizes the generations of family members that nutured performers in the Upper Cumberland area and the community support that invested in that talent and provided a stage. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1984. Each summer during those years, folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. They conducted interviews, took photos, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cayce and Donnie Russell Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Macon County residents Cayce Russell and Donnie Russell recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Accompanied by his wife Donnie, Cayce Russell, a well-known banjo player, singer, and storyteller, provides a wide variety of traditional songs, ghost stories, humorous tales, and insight into Grand Ole Opry personalities.

Cayce Russell's contribution reflects the history of old time music and instruments, provides historical events of his home county and the Cumberland Plateau, and furnishes history of the early years of the Grand Ole Opry. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Folklorists stationed in Tennessee's state parks conducted interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Claude Chessor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Dickson County resident Claude Chessor, born in Hickman County, recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Chessor discusses dulcimer making, dulcimer design, and dulcimer playing. He performs examples of ballads, old time music, country music and religious music on different types of dulcimers.

Chessor's contribution illustrates the expert craftsmanship required to design and handmake cypress-top, spruce-top, and cherry dulcimers. He also provides the listener with variety of sound, as he plays music on these different kinds of heritage instruments. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. From bases in state parks, folklorists conducted interviews, took photos, and recorded music.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chickasaw festival Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of attendees at Chester County's West Tennessee Folklife Festival including Lottie "Wolf" Murrell, Ed Harris, James Tatum, Annie Marie Valentine, and Gorland Tull. African American blues, religious, and fife and drum performances are given. Guitar ballads and old time string band music are also heard. Toasts, jokes, storytelling, and games are conveyed. Notable tale of Hurst Nation during the Civil War is included.

The Folklife Project generated a number of events and festivals revolving around its objectives. This West Tennessee Folklife Festival or Chickasaw State Park Folklife Festival was one such event. Today, festivals such as the Fall Creek Falls Folk Festival and the Louie Bluie Festival at Cove Lake Park continue as an outgrowth of the Folklife Project.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Johnson Swafford Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bledsoe County resident Johnson Swafford describes homemade instruments such as hide and cheese box banjos, gourd fiddles, and the mouth bow. Swafford makes banjos, fiddles, dulcimers, and mandolins, and he relates his processes. Swafford remembers shape-note singing schools in the area, where songs were sung a cappella, and the schools would end with a revival. He talks of candy pulls, ice cream socials, buck dancing, square dancing, and logging activities that fostered community spirit.

"Old-Time" Baptists brought traditions of lined a cappella singing with them into northeastern Tennessee. Eighteenth century northern ministers with their "Singing School Movement of New England" spawned the shape-note type singing that appeared in Tennessee. This combination of text, the use of shapes for musical notation, and the voicing of a song's notation prior to singing it was promoted by the increased availability of four-shape-note songbooks.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Shape-note singing; World War, 1939-1945; Square dance music--United States; Singing schools; Radio programs; Musical Instruments; Violin; Dulcimer and violin music

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clay Childers Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of McNairy County resident Clay Childers recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Childers relates his family history and stories of the family farm. He touches on moonshining and Civil War stories of the Battle of Shiloh. He describes fashioning chairs and musical instruments and building log cabins. He plays guitar and performs religious, old time, and country music selections.

Childers's contribution conveys McNairy County social and agricultural history. His tales of barn raisings and log cabin building reflect aspects of McNairy County folk architecture. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. From bases in Tennessee's state parks, folklorists conducted summer interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clay Childers Part 4
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of McNairy County resident Clay Childers recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Childers relates his family history and stories of the family farm. He touches on moonshining and Civil War stories of the Battle of Shiloh. He describes fashioning chairs and musical instruments and building log cabins. He plays guitar and performs religious, old time, and country music selections.

Childers's contribution conveys McNairy County social and agricultural history. His tales of barn raisings and log cabin building reflect aspects of McNairy County folk architecture. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. From bases in Tennessee's state parks, folklorists conducted summer interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Caldwell
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Hardin County resident Jim Caldwell recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Caldwell conveys stories of his personal and family history. He describes the methods of one of his occupations, water-witching or dousing using a divining rod. Caldwell also provides an account of digging and repairing wells. He relates tales of healing warts and thrash, horse trading, and moonshining.

The Tennessee folk custom of dousing has ancient origins and accompanying controversy. Dousing references are said to exist in Tassili cave art, Egyptian engravings, Chinese etchings, and Biblical passages. The practice would spread across Europe, and a forked stick, wand, pendulum, or metal rod would be utilized to locate water, mineral ore, and information beyond logical reason. Dousing also carries with it a connection to healing, as demonstrated by Caldwell's contribution.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Linnie Johnson and Jesse Robinson Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of White County neighbors Linnie Johnson and Jesse Robinson, both born in Dekalb County, recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Johnson performs unaccompanied ballads and old time music, and there are discussions concerning the backgrounds of the songs. Together, they relay tales of ghosts, haints, hangings, and murders. Anecdotes concerning the Ku Klux Klan and Night Riders are included.

The contributions of Johnson and Robinson convey both musical and social history of the Upper Cumberland area. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. From those bases, they conducted interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Andrew Jones Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Lake County resident Andrew Jones recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Jones relates family history, personal philosophy, and tales of medicine shows. He performs blues selections accompanying himself on the guitar; he "makes strings talk." Jones provides, as well, examples of African American toasts.

Jones's contribution brings to light the African American verbal art tradition of the toast. These long verses or recitations can be traced back to the time of Reconstruction, and they flourished in both rural and urban settings. Toasts can also be referred to as "brags," and these largely male, heroic expressions can be laced with street slang, obscenities, and misogynistic views.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jewel Allen Part 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Audio files of Fayette County resident Jewel Allen recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Allen conveys family history, humorous tales and jokes, as well as an anecdote dealing with slavery. Allen related his methods for bottoming chairs with corn shucks and piecing quilts. Allen was born in Hardeman County.

Allen's contribution highlights the transmittal of skills such as chair caning and quilting through African American family networks and how these skills served as financial safety nets in hard times. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. From bases at state parks, folklorists conducted summer interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Claude Chessor sits on swing
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Images of Claude Chessor playing dulcimer on his front porch in Lyles, Tennessee. Dickson County resident Claude Chessor, born in Hickman County, discusses dulcimer making, dulcimer design, and dulcimer playing with folklorists from the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. He performs examples of ballads, old time music, country music and religious music on different types of dulcimers.

Chessor's contribution illustrates the expert craftsmanship required to design and handmake cypress-top, spruce-top, and cherry dulcimers. He also provides the listener with variety of sound, as he plays music on these different kinds of heritage instruments. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. From bases in state parks, folklorists conducted interviews, took photos, and recorded music.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Emanuel (Manny) Dupree making baskets
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fayette County resident Emanuel Dupree is seated amidst his basket making supplies, holding rolled up white oak splits, and working on a split white oak basket at his home five miles south of Somerville, Tennessee.

Emanuel Dupree's contribution beautifully illustrates the transmittal of folk art skills through African American family networks. Dupree has been called one of the leading 20th century makers of split baskets. His Fayette County fife and drum band gained national attention and joined the list of surviving black fife and drum bands in Mississippi and Georgia. This tradition, arising in the South after the Civil War, and loosely based on militia bands, centered around performances at summer holiday picnics.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Taylor Jefferson (T. J.) Box lifting Henry Leatherwood
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: T. J. Box is pictured lifting his male friends, Henry Leatherwood and then Harry Gibbs, in his arms.

During the course of his life, Box pursued agricultural work, migrant work, work in a canning plant, and life insurance. His travels took him to California, Florida, Alabama, and Arkansas. Born in Lawrence County, Tennessee, he would eventually come back to the state of his birth and reside in the Blue Goose Community, outside Lexington, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Workyard tools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Images of chair caning supplies, tools, and the workyard used by Emanuel Dupree. Dupree, a third generation white oak basket maker and chair bottomer or caner, describes in his contributions to the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project the processes and how he learned. This African American woodcrafter also relates performing in local fife and drum bands and the accompanying celebrations.

Dupree's contribution beautifully illustrates the transmittal of folk art skills through African American family networks. Dupree has been called one of the leading 20th century makers of split baskets. His Fayette County fife and drum band gained national attention and joined the list of surviving black fife and drum bands in Mississippi and Georgia. This tradition, arising in the South after the Civil War, and loosely based on militia bands, centered around performances at summer holiday picnics.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fife and drum
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: West Tennessee fife and drum band members performing outdoors. Ed Harris plays the fife, and Emanuel Dupree sings "Hurry Down Sundown."

The Fayette County fife and drum band represented by this contribution gained national attention and joined the list of surviving black fife and drum bands in Mississippi and Georgia. This tradition, arising in the South after the Civil War, and loosely based on militia bands, centered around black community picnics. The picnics occurred during the summer and often on holidays such as July Fourth or Labor Day.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Tatum
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: West Tennessee fife and drum band member James Tatum sits back in a chair outdoors, cigarette in hand, and relates toasts.

Tatum's contribution brings to light the African American verbal art tradition of the toast. These long verses or recitations can be traced back to the time of Reconstruction, and they flourished in both rural and urban settings. Toasts can also be referred to as "brags," and these largely male, heroic expressions can be laced with street slang, obscenities, and misogynistic views.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wooden sculpture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Wooden animal, possibly a monkey, carved from a sassafras root by Willard Walton. Walton, a folk artist, performer, and sassafras tea seller, uses his woodworking and whittling skills to create animals from tree stumps and tree roots.

Walton's contribution highlights a multi-medium folk artist inspired by his family history, his natural surroundings, his life experiences, and his military service in India. His woodcraft gained national prominence, and advertisements for his walking sticks appeared in New York Magazine as early as the 1970s. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wooden sculpture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Creature carved from sassafras wood by Willard Walton. Walton, a folk artist, performer, and sassafras tea seller, uses his woodworking and whittling skills to create animals from tree stumps and tree roots.

Walton's contribution highlights a multi-medium folk artist inspired by his family history, his natural surroundings, his life experiences, and his military service in India. His woodcraft gained national prominence, and advertisements for his walking sticks appeared in New York Magazine as early as the 1970s. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Log cabin
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small chinked log cabin, with porch and shingled roof. This log house on Cedars of Lebanon Park land was once the family home of Dick Huddleston. Long-time Wilson County resident Dick Huddleston became a Cedars of Lebanon park employee. He passed along valuable information concerning local architectcure and farms and businesses that existed in the area before the establishment of the Cedars of Lebanon State Park through his Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project audio recordings.

The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. They conducted interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mr. McKinley Mackie is pictured seated in a chair at his residence in the Fairfield Community of Cumberland County. Mackie, his wife, and family produce handmade quilts. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Huddleston's Chicken Powder cardboard box
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image of a collapsed Huddleston's Chicken Powder cardboard box. A drawing of a chicken is featured, and the reputation of sixty-year veteran chicken breeder G. Peck Huddleston is touted. The powder is said to cure cholera, limp neck, roupe, lice, and mites. It is to function as a preventative, a restorer of life and vigor, and an enhancer of egg production. The medicine company was located in Lebanon and related to the family of Cedars of Lebanon State Park's first park ranger, Dick Huddleston.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main highway in Norene, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Published image identified as the main highway looking south in Norene, Tennessee. The town was formerly Henderson's Crossroads; its name was changed to Norene in 1918. The dirt road is flanked by the town's post office and Gulf gas station in the foreground. In the background, the Robbins Grocery appears. A variety of automobiles and individuals are also present in the image, as well as additional unidentified structures.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Log structure
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pictured is a single-room log pen structure with a metal roof located near Ozone, Tennessee. Its original function could have been that of a corncrib or a smokehouse. A number of tools, tubs, barrels, and farm implements positioned in and around the building are featured in the image. A covered tiller sits in front of the structure, and barrels for collecting water sit to the side.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Perry Lee Durham playing banjo
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Self-taught banjo player Perry Lee Durham is pictured sitting on the porch of his residence near Deer Lodge, Tennessee singing and playing his instrument. Durham was born in Fentress County. He made a living mining, farming, and working at a saw mill. His contributions to the project deal with old time banjo music, coal mining, and the Davidson Wilder Mine.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dollhouse
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dollhouse carved by Polly Page

Polly Page received the 2013 Tennessee Folklife Heritage Award honoring her accomplishments as a woodcarver. She enrolled in the arts and craft program at Pleasant Hill Academy in 1929 and learned carving under the direction of Margaret Campbell. Page played a leading role in the success of the Pleasant Hill Community Crafts program, arising after the closure of the Academy in the 1940s. Jane Fonda's character in the 1981 movie "The Dollmaker" was inspired by Polly Page.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joe Qualls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Joe Qualls is pictured seated on the front porch of his Crossville home. Qualls, born near Livingston, Tennessee, also lived in Oklahoma, Ohio, Florida, and Texas over the course of his life. He engaged in farming, mining, teaching, and factory work. His contribution to the project touched on Civil War stories, coal mining, the Davidson Wilder mine, murders, and rural schools. Around 1910, Qualls taught in a one-room schoolhouse in Overton County.

The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. From those bases, they conducted interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Red and white Star of the East variation quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Red and white Star of the East variation quilt, hanging on a clothes line. The quilt belonged to Belle and Clyde Williams, a brother and sister from Watertown, Tennessee. [Belle Williams] may be seen, seated in a lawn chair, to the right of the quilt.

The star design has played a prominent role in quilt patterns since the early 1800s, with the most common being the Bethlehem Star or Lone Star pattern. The Bethlehem Star pattern features a large central star made up of many small diamonds of; fabric. The fabric is usually multi-colored, giving the star a kaleidoscope effect. Around the time of the Civil War, a pattern known as the Ohio Star became popular. Most stars in quilt patterns have four, six, or eight rays.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Honeycomb quilt top
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Honeycomb pattern unquilted quilt top, hanging on a clothes line. The quilt top is multicolored and belonged to Belle and Clyde Williams, a brother and sister from Watertown, Tennessee.

The Honeycomb pattern is a traditional one-patch quilt pattern made up of hexagon shaped pieces. Hexagon quilts (like the Honeycomb, Mosaic, and Grandmother's Flower Garden) are usually very time consuming and labor intensive to make with all the pieces being stitched together by hand, typically using a method of construction known as English Paper Piecing. In the English Paper Piecing technique, a paper template is used to back the fabric pieces in order to help sew complex angles together accurately.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Double wedding ring quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Double Wedding Ring pattern quilt, hanging on a clothes line. The quilt has a flower motif quilted inside each ring and is finished with a scalloped edge binding technique. The quilt belonged to Belle and Clyde Williams, a brother and sister from

While there is much myth surrounding the origins of the Double Wedding Ring pattern, its earliest known publication was in 1928 in Capper's Weekly, a newspaper published by Arthur Capper in Topeka, Kansas. According to folk tradition, if a couple; received this quilt as a gift and slept under it, their marriage would be long and happy. Another bit of folklore implies that if a single girl makes a Double Wedding Ring and gives it to the gentleman of her choosing he will soon be her husband.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Log cabin quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Log Cabin pattern quilt, hanging on a clothes line. Log Cabin blocks can be placed in different configurations to make overall designs. The Log Cabin blocks in this quilt have been placed in a design commonly referred to as Streak of Lightning.

While English examples of the Log Cabin quilt pattern are known to exist dating back to the 1830s, it did not become popular in America until around the time of the Civil War. Traditionally, the center of each block represents the hearth of the cabin; and would be made with a red piece of fabric to resemble fire. Each log is then added around the hearth, overlapping the one before, until the cabin is built. Light and dark colors are alternated to represent life containing both joy and sorrow.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Men with logs and Stearns Railroad train
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ten unidentified men are pictured surrounded by logs, a log loader, and the back part of an engine, part of a Stearns Railroad logging train. This would be work being done out of Stearns Logging's Thompson Camp.

Egbert Atkinson's images illustrate the impact northern commercial lumber and coal ventures arriving in the Big South Fork area between 1900 and 1920 had on Scott, Pickett, and Fentress Counties. Michigan-based Stearns Coal and Lumber Company formed in 1902. The company purchased large amounts of land in the Big South Fork area and hugely impacted communities for decades. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jewel Allen's home in Whiteville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pictured is the home of basket maker Jewel Allen in Whiteville. The garden shown in the image belongs to Gus Hicks.

Allen's contribution highlights the transmittal of skills such as chair caning and quilting through African American family networks and how these skills served as financial safety nets in hard times. The Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. From bases at state parks, folklorists conducted summer interviews, took photographs, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wheelbarrow with metal wheel
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rustic handmade wooden wheelbarrow with a metal wheel used by Emanuel Dupree in his workyard is pictured. Dupree, a third generation white oak basket maker and chair bottomer or caner, describes in his contributions to the project the processes and how he learned. This African American woodcrafter also relates performing in local fife and drum bands and the accompanying celebrations.

Dupree's contribution beautifully illustrates the transmittal of folk art skills through African American family networks. Dupree has been called one of the leading 20th century makers of split baskets. His Fayette County fife and drum band gained national attention and joined the list of surviving black fife and drum bands in Mississippi and Georgia. This tradition, arising in the South after the Civil War, and loosely based on militia bands, centered around performances at summer holiday picnics.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oak Grove Church of Christ Gospel Group Chester County
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oak Grove Acapella Singers of Chester County being recorded while singing in the office of the preacher at the Oak Grove Church of Christ. Fifteen members comprise this unaccompanied African American religious musical group centered around the Oak Grove Church of Christ of Jacks Creek, Tennessee. Gospel songs feature solos by several of the members.

The contribution of the Oak Grove Acapella Singers conveys the power of African American gospel and the rich tradition of a capella singing within the Church of Christ. The Tennessee State Folklife Project began in 1979 under the direction of Park Ranger Bobby Fulcher and continued until 1983. Each summer during those years, three folklorists were stationed in Tennessee's state parks. From those bases, they conducted interviews, took photos, and recorded music with local tradition-bearers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fife and Drum Interview
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Folklorist Ray Allen (right) interviews Ed Harris outside

The Fayette County fife and drum band represented by this contribution gained national attention and joined the list of surviving black fife and drum bands in Mississippi and Georgia. This tradition, arising in the South after the Civil War, and loosely based on militia bands, centered around black community picnics. The picnics occurred during the summer and often on holidays such as July Fourth or Labor Day.
